bibl.title: Letter from William C. Borden to Howard A. Kelly, March 16, 1905

div1.p: Borden provides details of the surgical operation for appendicitis that immediately preceded Walter Reed's death.

div1.head: Letter from William C. Borden to Howard A. Kelly, March 16, 1905
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
U. S. A. General Hospital,
WASHINGTON BARRACKS.
Washington, D. C., March 16th, 1905.
Dr. HOWARD A. KELLY,
1418 Eutaw Place,
BALTIMORE, MD.
Dear Doctor Kelly:-
div1.p:
In reply to your request for information
relative to the operation and death of Dr. Reed, I take pleasure
in enclosing you a copy of the report made by me a short time
after the operation was done.

In addition to the fact therein set forth, I might say that
Dr. Reed had suffered for years with what he considered attacks
of acute indigestion, and that he had never suspected that the
trouble was appendicitis, although it undoubtedly was. The
appendix showed marked evidence of previous inflammatory action,
the lumen being nearly obliterated in several places. The o-
bliteration was, however, not distal, so that it cannot be con-
sidered a case of appendicitis obliterans. As stated in the
report, Dr. Reed's symptoms in no way indicated the gravity of
the intra-abdominal trouble, and when I started to operate I
expected to find a case of ordinary catarrhal appendicitis, an
appendix in which the inflammatory action was still limited.
At the operation the condition was found as stated in the report.
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
The site of operation was carefully walled off, but in manipu-
lating the appendix the pus cavity was opened. The pus was all
carefully sponged out with gauze sponges and I believe none of
it escaped from the gauze crater. The appendix was so necrotic
at the base that it was simply ligated off. No invagination of
the stomachstump could be done owing to the necrotic condition of the
caecum in the neighborhood. Gauze drainage was inserted, the
lower end of the drain being carefully packed over the stomachstump
and down into the space between the peritonealposterior abdominal wall
and lower end of the caecum, where the pus had gravitated. The
Surgeon General of the Army--Brigadier General R. M. O'Reilly--
Major Jefferson R. Kean, and other medical officers, as well as
Dr. Wallace Neff of this city, were present at the operation. The
operation was not prolonged, although I have forgotten the exact
length of time--probably 1/2 hour. Dr. Reed reacted badly. He
was very nervous and was much run down before the operation from
overwork. He had been doing a great deal of extra bacteriological
work and had been much confined, so that altogether his general
condition at the time of operation was very unsatisfactory. This
probably accounts, in part, for his reacting so badly. From the
subsequent course of the case I am inclined to think that peri-
tonitis gradually spread from the vicinity of the stump of the
appendix, although he did very well for the first three days after
the operation, so well, in fact, that the drain was not removed
until the fourth day, being left in with the hope that by that
time the infected area would be well walled off. Still there
was suspicious evidence of peritoneal involvement in the right
3
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
and lower regions of the abdomen. The drain was removed without
trouble, and apparently without breaking down any adhesions or
interfering with the gut. The next day faecal matter in large
quantity came through the wound, snowing that the caecum had
broken down at or near the place where the appendix was ligated
off. The opening must have been of considerable size as the
quantity discharged was large. Shortly after the appearance of
the faecal matter the symptoms of extensive peritonitis appeared,
proceedpreceded by symptoms which indicated a rupture into the general
peritoneal cavity, and I believe that the necrotic caecum slough-
ed through causing general peritoneal infection. From this time
forward Dr. Reed rapidly grew worse and died the next day--the
sixth day after the operation.

Relative to information regarding his last days, I think
there is little which can be said which would be of interest.
Dr. Reed, aside from being excessively nervous, in fact unusually
nervous, due, as I attribute it, to his mental fatigue from prev-
ious overwork and consequent nervous collapse, was generally
cheerful and unapprehensive of any ill result. After the appear-
ance of the faecal fistula and the probable rupture into the
general peritoneal cavity, he suffered from partial collapse and
thereafter grew rapidly worse and soon became delirious.

The case was a particularly trying one to me for the reason
that I was a great personal friend of Dr. Reed's, had known him
for many years, and his family and my own are intimately acquainted.
The case was also particularly unfortunate to me professionally,
in that it is the only operative case of appendicitis which I
have ever lost, although I have operated a large number of times.
It seemed particularly unfortunate that of the cases operated
upon by me, that Dr. Reed should be the only one to die.

If there are any other particulars which you would like to
know, I would be very glad to inform you in regard to them.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, W. C. Borden
Major, Surgeon, U. S. Army. FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
